Error bars show the 90% confidence interval. Dashed lines in panel i show the annual mean NOx climatology from the control simulations.Full size imageAerosol optical depth (AOD; Fig. 3d) features larger increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and aerosol direct radiative effect (ADRE; Fig. 3e) at the top-of-the-atmosphere (TOA) features larger decreases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Again, this is more pronounced in the SH, where ADRE decreases by \(-0.15\pm 0.02\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(-0.04\pm 0.01\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). In contrast, the TOA cloud radiative effect (CRE; Fig. 3f) is less negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). In the SH, the CRE is \(-0.13\pm 0.07\) W m−2 versus \(-0.22\pm 0.11\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), respectively (Supplementary Table 4). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is positive but not significant in both hemispheres at \(0.09\pm 0.13\) W m−2 in the SH and \(0.08\pm 0.11\) W m-2 in the NH. The strengthening (more negative) of the ADRE but weakening (less negative) of the CRE under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is emphasized in Supplementary Fig. 3. We note that this weakening of the CRE (albeit non-significant) applies to both hemispheres. These zonal mean results are in general consistent with the SEB decomposition (which only includes land areas with >0.1 tree fraction change), where the influence of SWclear (which is impacted by aerosol direct effect) is more negative (i.e., stronger) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) than \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), yet the influence of SWcloud (in the SH) is less negative (i.e., weaker). On the other hand, these zonal mean results suggest that the reduced cooling from clouds under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is also important in the higher-latitude NH (where it was weak based on the SEB analysis; Fig. 2a).We also note larger tropospheric ozone (TO3) burden decreases in the SH under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 3g), larger decreases in OH burden at all latitudes (Fig. 3h) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and similar decreases in nitrogen oxide (NOx) burden across most latitudes for both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The larger SH TO3 decrease under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.59\pm 0.04\) DU versus \(-0.19\pm 0.04\) DU under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)) is consistent with the larger increase in BVOCs (e.g., isoprene; Fig. 3a), which are oxidized by TO3 and OH. The NH TO3 increase (largely in the NH mid-latitudes) is consistent with the increase in BVOCs (especially isoprene) under higher climatological NOx concentrations (Fig. 3i), which drives TO3 production. Here, the NH TO3 increase is weaker under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.03\pm 0.05\) DU versus \(0.12\pm 0.04\) DU under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)), which is largely related to stronger TO3 decreases in the NH tropics (where NOx is relatively low). The larger decrease in SH TO3 (a greenhouse gas) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is inconsistent with the similar SH near-surface air temperature response under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), suggesting the change in TO3 is not a dominant contributor to the surface temperature response. This is consistent with ref. 24, where the global annual mean ozone instantaneous radiative effect associated with our tree restoration perturbation under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is very small at \(0.001\pm 0.00023\) W m−2 (\(-0.005\pm 0.00025\) W m−2 in the SH and \(0.006\pm 0.00045\) W m−2 in the NH).Air quality responsesFigure 4 shows changes in near-surface fine particulate matter (PM2.5), a commonly used quantity to diagnose air quality. In the NH, PM2.5 over land increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.39\pm 0.12\) μg m−3) with weak decreases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.07\pm 0.12\) μg m−3; although some regions like North America yield increases). The weak decrease under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is related to compensating increases in SOA but decreases in dust (Supplementary Table 3). The net PM2.5 increase under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.46\pm 0.17\) μg m−3) is due to the larger increase in SOA dominating over weaker decreases in dust. In the SH, both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yield increases in PM2.5 over land at \(1.10\pm 0.07\) and \(0.31\pm 0.07\) μg m−3, respectively, with net increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.79\pm 0.10\) μg m−3). Increases are particularly prominent over Brazil, where PM2.5 increases exceed 10 μg m−3 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).Fig. 4: Near-surface fine particulate matter responses to global tree restoration.Near-surface fine particulate matter (PM2.5; μg m−3) a–c spatial maps and d, e zonal mean land-only responses. Responses are estimated from CAM6 simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry coupled to a slab ocean model over the last 150 years of the simulation (years 50–199).Full size imageReduced dust burden under tree restoration is consistent with reduced near-surface wind speeds (due to enhanced surface roughness), as discussed in ref. 24 (e.g., see Supplementary Fig. 12 from that paper). For example, near-surface wind speeds over land decrease by \(-0.11\pm 0.01\) m s−1 under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}.\) The weaker surface winds, in turn, favor less dust emissions, with similar decreases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., dust emissions nonsignificantly decrease by \(-44.1\pm 85.4\) Tg year−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).Consistent with the standard approach in most current climate models, our simulations do not include interactive fire emissions (see the “Methods” section) of PM2.5 and its precursors. They are instead read in from a time-varying emissions file (here fixed in the base year of 2000). As discussed below, fire carbon emissions do change in response to our tree restoration perturbation, including significant global increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), largely in the NH (Supplementary Table 5). This implies the above-quoted PM2.5 increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) are likely an underestimate, at least in the areas downwind of where there are increases in fire activity.Supplementary Figure 4 shows changes in near-surface ozone (O3), another commonly used quantity to diagnose air quality. Over land in the NH, O3 increases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.90\pm 0.07\) ppb) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.78\pm 0.07\) ppb), with net increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.12\pm 0.10\) ppb). Some regions (e.g., central US) experience relatively large increases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (>5 ppb or a 20–25% increase relative to the control), which is consistent with relatively high levels on NOx (based on the year 2000 baseline) and BVOCs, leading to enhanced O3. In the SH, the opposite occurs with decreases under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.86\pm 0.04\) ppb) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.14\pm 0.04\) ppb), with net decreases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(-0.71\pm 0.05\) ppb). The SH features smaller levels of NOx, and here the enhanced BVOC oxidation of O3 dominates, with the larger increase in BVOCs (e.g., Fig. 3a, b) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yielding a larger decrease in O3. We also note that these O3 changes are also consistent with changes in ozone deposition velocity (estimated as monthly ozone dry deposition flux divided by monthly near-surface ozone concentration; Supplementary Fig. 5). For example, over NH land (where O3 increases) ozone deposition velocity strongly decreases by \(-0.091\pm 0.004\) mm s−1 under \({{TREE}}_{2{xCo}2}\) and by \(-0.087\pm 0.003\) mm s−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 3). NH decreases in ozone deposition velocity with tree restoration may occur following decreases in transpiration that follow the displacement of highly productive crops and grasses as well as decreased near-surface wind speed that follows increases in roughness and leads to less efficient vertical transport of ozone (see supplement of ref. 24). In the SH, ozone deposition velocity weakly increases by \(0.0033\pm 0.0031\) mm s−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (where O3 decreases), with decreases of \(-0.025\pm 0.002\) mm s−1 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (where O3 increases). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) spatial correlations for the NH and SH land are \(-0.81\) and \(-0.22\), respectively (\(-0.66\) for global land). For \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), the NH and SH land correlations are \(-0.88\) and \(-0.46\), respectively (\(-0.80\) for global land). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) effects on ozone deposition velocity are mostly at higher mid-latitudes, and they are decreases. These decreases occur despite strong increases in LAI under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), which may be due to compensatory changes in individual depositional processes55,56. Enhanced ozone deposition velocity under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in the SH largely follows enhanced LAI there. This is likely due to enhanced cuticular uptake, as stomatal uptake largely decreases. Cuticular uptake is independent of stomatal uptake and occurs when ozone reacts with compounds adhered to or a part of leaf cuticles.Overall, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields degraded air quality in the NH for both O3 and PM2.5. In the SH, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields improved air quality in terms of O3, but degraded air quality in terms of PM2.5. These statements are more pronounced over regions with large tree restoration (e.g., Brazil).Fire and land carbon responsesFigure 5 shows the fire carbon emissions response to tree restoration. \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields overall (global) decreases in fire carbon emissions at \(-195.8\pm 30.7\) TgC year−1 (\(-10.9\)%), with significant decreases in the tropics (30S-30N) of \(-307.7\pm 27.5\) TgC year−1 (\(-22.1\)%) outweighing significant increases in the NH extratropics (NHE; 30–60 N) and SH extratropics (SHE; 30–60S) at \(96.1\pm 10.8\) TgC year−1 (\(34.2\)%) and \(16.2\pm 6.2\) TgC year−1 (\(13.4\)%), respectively (Supplementary Table 5). Similar conclusions apply under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), but with muted global decreases (\(-46.9\pm 39.8\) TgC year−1), i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields a net increase of \(148.9\pm 47.9\) TgC year−1. This is mostly related to larger increases under \({{{\rm{TREE}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{Co}}}}}_{2}}\) in the NHE (\(162.1\pm 18.4\) TgC year−1) and weaker decreases in the tropics (\(-218.5\pm 36.0\) TgC year−1) i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields net increases in the NHE and tropics of \(65.9\pm 21.3\) and \(89.2\pm 42.1\) TgC year−1, respectively. These signals are partially offset by weaker increases in the SHE (\(9.3\pm 4.0\) TgC year−1) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields nonsignificant net decreases of \(-6.9\pm 7.4\) TgC year−1). Thus, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) exacerbates fire carbon emissions (and fire burned area), largely in the NHE and tropics.Fig. 5: Fire responses to global tree restoration.a–e Fire carbon emissions [kgC km−2 day−1] responses based on simulations with interactive chemistry under a \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and b \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and c \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). For example, the NHE features significant net cooling as well as net moistening based on both relative humidity at 2 m (RH2M) and soil water in the top 10 cm (SW10CM) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 5). Near-surface wind speeds do feature significant net increases in the NHE, but this is a smaller decrease under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). We suspect the increase in fire carbon emissions under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in the NHE and the weaker decrease in the tropics is related to the warmer and drier background climate. Comparing the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate versus the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate shows very large NHE increases in fire carbon emissions of 167%, as well as strong NHE drying based on RH2M (\(-2.0 \%\)) and, in particular, based on SW10CM \((-9.7 \% )\)). Similar but weaker drying occur in the tropics. Interestingly, the opposite changes occur in the SHE, where fire carbon emissions nonsignificantly decrease by \(-3.3 \%\), RH2M significantly increases by \(1.9 \%\), and SW10CM weakly decreases by \(-0.6 \%\). Thus, the larger NHE increase (and smaller tropical decrease) in fire carbon emissions under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) appears to be related to the warmer and drier background climate. This argument also helps to explain the weaker SHE increase in fire carbon emissions under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), where drying is muted (e.g., RH2M increases).Land carbon (the sum of vegetation, litter, and soil organic matter carbon) increases under both \({TREE}_{2xCo2}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 6a–c), with larger increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Similar statements apply to vegetation carbon (Fig. 6d–f), litter carbon (Fig. 6g–i) and soil organic matter carbon (Fig. 6j–l), with vegetation carbon dominating the increase. By the last decade of the simulation (years 190–199), global land carbon (Fig. 6c) increases by \(306.1\pm 1.9\) PgC under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(210.3\pm 0.7\) PgC under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Supplementary Table 6). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) therefore yields enhanced land carbon storage of \(95.8\pm 1.0\) PgC, which represents a 46% increase relative to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Similarly, the global increase in net primary productivity (NPP; Supplementary Table 5) is larger under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(2257.5\pm 280.6\) TgC year−1 as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(700.3\pm 193.4\) TgC year−1. This enhanced NPP and land carbon storage response under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with the carbon fertilization effect57,58,59,60.Fig. 6: Land carbon time series.Global annual mean a–c vegetation + litter + soil organic matter carbon; d–f vegetation carbon; g–i litter carbon; and j–l soil organic matter carbon responses for the a, d, g, j Northern Hemisphere; b, e, h, k Southern Hemisphere; and c, f, I, l globe. Units are PgC.Full size imageThe transient climate response to cumulative CO2 emissions (TCRE) represents a near-linear relationship between cumulative anthropogenic CO2 emissions and global warming since the preindustrial, and provides an approximation of the near-surface air temperature response to land carbon changes32,33,34,35. We note that there is uncertainty in using this approach to quantify the biogeochemical cooling effects associated with tree restoration. Ideally, emissions-driven simulations would be employed, which directly simulate the carbon cycle and allow a direct estimate of the biogeochemical effects associated with tree restoration. This includes compensation by the marine carbon sink as atmospheric CO2 decreases in response to an increase in terrestrial carbon storage61,62,63.Using the CESM2 TCRE value34 of 2.13 K per 1000 PgC and the increase in global land carbon storage (years 190–199) yields an estimate of the associated biogeochemical cooling of \(-0.65\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) versus \(-0.45\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields enhanced biogeochemical cooling of \(-0.20\) K. We note that the CESM2 TCRE is on the high end64, as the best estimate is 1.65 K per 1000 PgC, with a likely range from 1.0 to 2.3 K per 1000 PgC.ERF and radiative kernel decompositionFigure 7 shows the instantaneous radiative forcing (IRF), total adjustment (Totaladj) and effective radiative forcing (ERF, which is the sum of IRF and Totaladj; see the “Methods” section) from analogous tree restoration simulations with climatologically fixed SSTs and sea-ice distributions (FSST; see the “Methods” section). IRF is estimated as the sum of the surface albedo radiative kernel (IRFalbedo) and the ADRE (IRFADRE; calculated online from double radiation calls). Although most ERFs are not significant, they qualitatively support the temperature responses from the corresponding SOM simulations. For example, NH ERF decreases from \(0.18\pm 0.10\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) to \(0.01\pm 0.16\) W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), consistent with muted NH warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Fig. 1). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) therefore yields a negative (but not significant) NH ERF of \(-0.17\pm 0.19\) W m−2, also consistent with NH net surface cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in SOM simulations. Similar results exist for the land surface corrected ERF (ERFts). Most of the negative ERF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is due to a less positive IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (i.e., the IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is \(-0.13\pm 0.06\) W m−2). This is associated with a less positive IRFalbedo (less surface darkening) and a more negative IRFADRE (consistent with more SOA) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). The corresponding \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) effects are \(-0.05\pm 0.03\) W m−2 for IRFalbedo and \(-0.08\pm 0.05\) W m−2 for IRFADRE. In addition to IRF, adjustments also impact ERF. Here, the cloud adjustment is less negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., there is a (nonsignificant) positive cloud adjustment under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) of \(0.06\pm 0.09\) W m−2 based on the kernel difference method (\(0.03\) W m−2 based on ISCCP Cloudadj). This positive cloud adjustment acts to mute some of the negative IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Note, however, that non-cloud adjustments (largely the tropospheric temperature adjustment) dominate and contribute to the decreased ERF (i.e., the Totaladj is negative but with large uncertainty at \(-0.04\pm 0.16\) W m−2). Thus, these FSST simulations support the above SOM analyses—most of the NH surface cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is consistent with less surface darkening and enhanced aerosol scattering (IRFalbedo and IRFADRE, respectively), which is partially weakened by clouds (23% for ISCCP Cloudadj and 46% for Cloudadj).Fig. 7: ERF and radiative kernel decomposition from fixed SST simulations.Annual mean TOA effective radiative forcing (ERF; black), land surface corrected ERF (ERFts; red), instantaneous radiative forcing (IRF; light green) which is decomposed into contributions from albedo (IRFalbedo; dark green) and aerosol direct radiative effects (IRFADRE; medium green), the cloud adjustment from the kernel difference method (Cloudadj; light pink) and from the ISCCP simulator combined with the ISCCP radiative kernel (ISCCP Cloudadj; dark pink) and the total adjustment (Totaladj; blue) for the a Northern Hemisphere and b Southern Hemisphere. ERFts yields somewhat more negative values (since it accounts for land cooling), but these are again not significant. \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) therefore has a negligible impact on SH ERF at \(-0.02\pm 0.15\) W m−2. This ERF analysis is consistent with similar SH cooling under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in SOM experiments (e.g., Fig. 1). However, the similar SH ERFs between \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) are associated with the importance of different terms. Under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), a weakly positive (nonsignificant) IRF of \(0.01\pm 0.02\) W m−2 occurs, which is due to a positive IRFalbedo of \(0.09\pm 0.01\) W m−2 (surface darkening) being largely negated by IRFADRE of \(-0.08\pm 0.02\) W m−2 (consistent with enhanced SOA). IRF under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is significantly larger at \(0.09\pm 0.11\) W m−2, which is essentially due to IRFalbedo. Thus, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields a negative SH IRF of \(-0.08\pm 0.02\) W m−2, largely due to IRFADRE. The cloud adjustment, however, is less negative under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.07\pm 0.09\) W m−2 as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.14\pm 0.10\) W m−2, i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields a net positive (but nonsignificant) cloud adjustment of \(0.07\pm 0.13\) W m−2 (ISCCP Cloudadj yields \(0.05\) W m−2). Furthermore, the SH cloud adjustment is comparable to the total adjustment under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (i.e., clouds dominate the total adjustment). Thus, this FSST analysis also supports the SH SOM results discussed above. Here, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) effects on albedo are small and enhanced cooling from aerosol direct radiative effects is largely offset (63% for ISCCP Cloudadj and 88% for Cloudadj) by enhanced warming from clouds. This helps to account for the similar SH near-surface air temperature responses under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).Similar conclusions also exist using the approximate partial radiative perturbation (APRP) decomposition65,66, which quantifies the components of shortwave ERF (longwave effects are not included here) attributed to cloud fraction change and all-sky and clear-sky absorption and scattering (Supplementary Figs. 6, 7). For example, under FSST simulations in the SH (Supplementary Fig. 6b), \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields a negative non-cloud adjustment (largely due to non-cloud scattering, consistent with enhanced SOA) of \(-0.09\) W m−2 versus a positive cloud adjustment of \(0.10\) W m−2. Thus, as above, enhanced cooling associated with aerosol direct effects is muted by clouds. Here, the positive cloud adjustment under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) has contributions from both cloud amount (\(0.04\) W m−2) and cloud scattering (\(0.07\) W m−2). This applies to both FSST simulations (Supplementary Fig. 6b) and SOM experiments (Supplementary Fig. 7b). As the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate features substantially more aerosols than the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline (e.g., global SOA burden increases by 147%), aerosol–cloud interactions in response to tree restoration may be weaker under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) due to a saturation effect, i.e., the cloud droplet number concentration to aerosol sensitivity decreases at large aerosol concentrations67. There is some cloud microphysical evidence (Supplementary Fig. 8) that supports this—although cloud condensation nuclei (CCN) concentration significantly increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.89\pm 0.11\) # cm−3), average cloud water number concentration (CDNC) and average droplet effective radius (Re) do not significantly change, particularly in the SH (where the cooling effect of the cloud response under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is muted most under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), e.g., Fig. 7). For example, CDNC nonsignificantly increases by \(0.06\pm 0.21\) # cm−3 and Re nonsignificantly decreases by \(-0.004\pm 0.022\) μm in the SH under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Another possible explanation is that the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate features significantly less cloud cover, particularly low- and mid-level cloud, than that under the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate. For example, there is \(-6.3\pm 0.8\)% and \(-9.3\pm 0.8\)% less low cover in the NH and SH, respectively, under the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) baseline climate (corresponding to percent changes of \(-17.5\)% and \(-21.1\)%, respectively). Such strong decreases in low- and mid-level cloud may act to weaken aerosol-cloud interactions associated with tree restoration in a warmer world.Simulations without interactive chemistryAnalogous \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) CAM6 SOM simulations without interactive atmospheric chemistry (NOCHEM) were also conducted24. The NOCHEM \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) effect on near-surface air temperature (Supplementary Fig. 9c) is similar to that under our default simulations with interactive atmospheric chemistry (abbreviated here as CHEM). NOCHEM \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields decreased global mean temperatures by \(-0.08\pm 0.03\) K, largely due to net cooling of the NH at \(-0.13\pm 0.05\) K as opposed to the SH at \(-0.02\pm 0.04\) K (Table 2). Based on the corresponding NOCHEM SEB decomposition, the muted NH warming under NOCHEM \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is again largely associated with less surface darkening (Supplementary Fig. 10a), i.e., the albedo term decreases by \(-0.18\pm 0.01\) K. Changes in NOCHEM downwelling surface solar radiation under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) are minimal, consistent with prescribed BVOCs and lack of SOA increases under tree restoration24. The SW term, for example, yields nonsignificant changes under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) of \(-0.01\pm 0.05\) K in the NH and \(0.02\pm 0.06\) K in the SH. In the SH, the weak (nonsignificant) cooling under NOCHEM \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is largely related to enhanced cooling from the LHF term (Supplementary Fig. 10b), which is consistent with larger increases in vegetation indices (e.g., LAI) and associated increases in canopy transpiration under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). For example, canopy transpiration (subsampled as in the SEB analysis) increases under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), particularly in the SH at \(0.97\pm 0.17\) W m−2. In contrast to this NOCHEM LHF cooling, LHF tends to yield net warming (in the SH) under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) in our default simulations with atmospheric chemistry (e.g., Fig. 2b). This difference is likely related to the increase in CHEM SOA and corresponding reductions in downwelling solar radiation, which acts to mute increases in latent heat flux.Table 2 Near-surface air temperature responses under tree restoration in simulations without interactive atmospheric chemistry (NOCHEM).Full size tableThe impact of atmospheric chemistry under higher atmospheric CO2 is better illustrated by looking at the double difference \({({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}})}_{{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{M}}}}}-{({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}})}_{{{{\rm{N}}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{M}}}}}\). Given the similar near-surface temperature responses in both CHEM and NOCHEM discussed above, \({({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}})}_{{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{M}}}}}-{({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}})}_{{{{\rm{N}}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{M}}}}}\) yields nonsignificant global (\(0.02\pm 0.05\) K) and hemispheric temperature responses (\(0.01\pm 0.07\) K in the NH and \(0.03\pm 0.06\) K in the SH; Table 2). The corresponding SEB decomposition (Supplementary Fig. 11) shows the importance of the SWclear term in CHEM relative to NOCHEM in driving net cooling in the NH (\(-0.10\pm 0.03\) K). In the SH, large SWclear cooling in CHEM relative to NOCHEM (\(-0.26\pm 0.03\) K) is offset by both the SWcloud term (\(0.14\pm 0.09\) K) as well as the LHF term (\(0.13\pm 0.09\) K). In other words, with NOCHEM, the SW response is muted in both hemispheres, which also leads to the omission of feedbacks with clouds and turbulent heat fluxes. A more comprehensive decomposition of the LHF term into canopy evaporation, ground evaporation, total evaporation and canopy transpiration terms is discussed in Supplementary Note 2 and Supplementary Figs. 12–14. Similar to the LHF term, the SHF term yields net warming under \({({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}})}_{{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{M}}}}}-{({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}})}_{{{{\rm{N}}}}{{{\rm{O}}}}{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{H}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{M}}}}}\) in both hemispheres at \(0.09\pm 0.04\) K in the NH and \(0.06\pm 0.08\) K in the SH (non-significant). This analysis further illustrates how an aerosol increase under tree restoration—particularly under higher CO2—drives SWclear cooling that is offset by both cloud effects as well as by reductions in latent and sensible heat cooling.DiscussionThe biogeophysical (including non-methane atmospheric chemistry) effects of tree restoration yield significant global mean warming of \(0.07\pm 0.03\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), which is reduced to nonsignificant warming of \(0.02\pm 0.03\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (Table 1). Thus, changes in the chemistry-climate effect of tree restoration due to CO2 doubling (i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\)) yield significant global mean cooling of \(-0.06\pm 0.04\) K. All of the cooling occurs in the NH (\(-0.12\pm 0.05\) K) as opposed to the SH (\(0.01\pm 0.04\) K). The muted warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) is largely associated with less surface darkening (largely in the NH), due to less snow in the warmer background climate. Enhanced aerosol direct radiative effects (less downwelling surface solar radiation) also contribute to the muted warming, but they are weakened by opposing cloud and, to some extent, turbulent heat flux effects. Of the \(-0.06\pm 0.04\) K global mean cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), atmospheric chemistry effects (without methane) contribute nonsignificantly at \(0.02\pm 0.05\) K (Table 2).When methane effects are accounted for (Table 1), global mean warming due to biogeophysical effects increases (using central estimates) from 0.02 to 0.15 K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and from 0.07 to 0.11 K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Thus, methane reverses the cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) from \(-0.06\) K to a warming of 0.04 K, i.e., biogeophysical effects with methane suggest more warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as compared to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). However, biogeochemical cooling (which is approximated from the TCRE; Table 1) is larger under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (associated with enhanced land carbon storage consistent with the CO2 fertilization effect) at \(-0.65\) versus \(-0.45\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields enhanced biogeochemical cooling of \(-0.20\) K. Thus, compensating effects exist under higher atmospheric CO2 concentrations, as they do for present-day CO2 levels24. However, biogeophysical warming (with methane) offsets a similar percentage of biogeochemical cooling at 23% for \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and 24% for \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). In both cases, biogeochemical cooling dominates the total (biogeophysical effects with methane + biogeochemical effects) near-surface air temperature response, with larger cooling under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.50\) K versus \(-0.34\) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). This result implies larger cooling (i.e., \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields \(-0.16\) K) due to the enhanced biogeochemical effects.However, some undesirable aspects of tree restoration are exacerbated under the warmer, higher CO2 background climate. This includes larger PM2.5 increases in both hemispheres under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) as opposed to \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), due to larger increases in SOA. Furthermore, larger increases in near-surface ozone occur in the NH (but larger decreases occur in the SH). The changes in ozone may depend on the anthropogenic NOx emissions used; for example, here we use emissions from 2000, which is marked by high NOx emissions in North America and Europe that have since decreased. Furthermore, fire carbon emissions increase more in the NH extratropics, and decrease less (i.e., net increase) in the tropics under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). As our simulations do not include interactive fire emissions of reactive trace gases and aerosols, the above estimate for the PM2.5 increase is likely an underestimate.Our analysis is based on a single model, and additional studies with alternative models should be pursued to evaluate the robustness of these results. For example, how BVOC emissions respond to climate is a major source of uncertainty, and we acknowledge that CESM2 tends to yield a relatively strong BVOC response to changes in climate68,69. Moreover, emissions-based simulations (as opposed to our concentration-based simulations) should be pursued to enable direct simulation of both the biogeophysical effects (with chemistry) as well as the biogeochemical effects. Such simulations would allow direct quantification of the biogeochemical effects, thereby avoiding reliance on the TCRE and the uncertainties associated with using it to approximate the biogeochemical cooling effects of tree restoration. Emissions-driven simulations would also (ideally) contain interactive fire emissions of reactive trace gases and aerosols, which would allow for improved estimates of the impact of tree restoration on air quality, as well as the associated fire feedbacks to the climate system. And finally, simulations with more realistic, transient tree restoration should be pursued in the future to provide a better understanding of the climate mitigation potential of tree restoration. Overall, however, we have provided a detailed mechanistic analysis of the impact of atmospheric CO2 on the climate effects of tree restoration, largely focused on the biogeophysical responses, including atmospheric chemistry. Although our analysis suggests that tree restoration is effective at mitigating climate change under continued warming, caveats exist, including enhanced particle pollution and wildfire activity.MethodsCAM6 simulationsOur \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) simulations are identical to those in ref. 24. We repeat the important details on our simulations here. We use the Community Earth System Model version 2 (CESM2)29 at 1.9° × 2.5° horizontal resolution and 32 vertical atmospheric levels. Components of CESM2 include the Community Atmosphere Model version 6 (CAM6), the Community Land Model version 5 (CLM5)31 and a slab ocean model70 integrated with the dynamic sea ice model, the Community Ice CodE version 5 (CICE5)71. CLM5 is run with active biogeochemistry, including prognostic vegetation and fires, which include agricultural, deforestation, non-peat and peat fires72,73. A land use time series file—which here is fixed to the baseline year of 2000—specifies vegetation distributions through time. Vegetation physiology, including leaf area index and canopy height, is prognostic. Baseline land-use data is based on satellite land cover descriptions, including MODIS land cover (MCD12Q1 v5.1), vegetation continuous fields (MOD44B v5.1), LAI (MCD15A2 v5), and albedo (MCD43B3 v5) products31. Additional information for tree leaf type and longevity is provided by the AVHRR continuous fields tree cover product74. Global crop distributions are provided by the monthly irrigated and rainfed crop areas around the year 2000 (MIRCA2000) data set75. Canopy height data for tree PFTs are provided by the Geoscience Laser Altimeter System on the ICESat satellite as processed by ref. 76.CLM’s fire module simulates burned area and carbon emissions. The associated biomass burning aerosol/precursor gas emissions are not simulated here. Fire occurrence depends on fuel load, fire suppression, ignitions, and fuel combustibility72,73,77. Ignition is parameterized as a function of lightning frequency (which is prescribed from observations) and population density. Both population and lightning frequency are identical in all of our simulations. The amount of vegetation and litter present in a grid cell determines fuel load. Soil moisture and relative humidity determine fuel combustibility. Wind speed determines fire spread. Fires also depend on socioeconomic factors, but these do not change in our simulations. Agricultural fire burned area is based on socioeconomic factors, fuel availability, fire seasonality and the area of cropland73. An equation that includes the effects of decreased tree fraction and climate conditions73 determines burned area for deforestation fires. Since each of our simulations features non-transient land cover, there are no deforestation fires. However, the decrease in crop fraction between the experiment and control will promote a decrease in fire-burned area for cropland. CLM5 also includes a prognostic representation of the terrestrial nitrogen cycle and its coupling to the land carbon cycle31.Sulfate, primary and aged black carbon, secondary organic aerosols, sea salt and dust are based on the Modal Aerosol Model with 4 modes (MAM4)78. The model for ozone and related chemical tracers (MOZART) troposphere stratosphere (TS1) chemistry mechanism30 is used for Interactive chemistry simulations, which includes 221 gas phase and aerosol species and 528 chemical and photochemical reactions, along with a volatility basis set (VBS) parameterization for the formation of secondary organic aerosols79 which generates gas-phase SOA precursors with a range of volatilities resulting from the oxidation of the aromatic species, terpenes, and isoprene. BVOCs, including isoprene and monoterpene, are simulated online based on atmospheric conditions (e.g., temperature, CO2) and land cover using the Model of Emissions of Gases and Aerosol from Nature (MEGAN) v2.149. The dependence of BVOC emissions on light and temperature and the inhibition of isoprene emissions based on atmospheric CO2 concentrations are included in MEGAN v2.1.The full dynamic sea ice model (CICE5) is used for our slab ocean simulations. A temporally and spatially prescribed ocean heat flux and mixed layer depth80,81 is also used. Fifty years of a spun-up CESM2 preindustrial simulation are used to generate the slab ocean model forcing data82.Baseline/control simulations are performed with year 2000 land-use/land cover conditions, and atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations and aerosol/precursor gas emissions. A previously integrated historical simulation is used to generate the initial land carbon pools for the year 2000. An identical set of simulations (i.e., the perturbation or experiment) is integrated, but the default land use data set is replaced with our tree restoration scenario. A control and a perturbed simulation are separately performed under present-day atmospheric CO2 concentrations and double present-day atmospheric CO2 concentrations. All experiments are integrated for 200 years. Climate responses are based on the last 150 years (i.e., the first 50 years is spin-up). This is in agreement with the leveling off of the global mean near-surface air temperature time series after 50 years. These relatively long simulations allow for improved separation of the forced signal and internal climate variability. We note that the biogeophysical effects are still developing, as the land carbon pools are not yet in equilibrium.Anthropogenic emissions associated with agricultural land use and all other sectors are identical in all simulations. These are based on the baseline year 2000. The only change to anthropogenic factors that is implemented in our experiments is doubling the atmospheric CO2 to obtain the \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) climate signal. Our goal is not to quantify the climate impacts of altered land use/land cover (where associated changes in anthropogenic emissions may be important). It is to quantify the impacts of a high-end tree restoration perturbation and to isolate the impacts of doubling CO2.We note here that our results are not sensitive to the analysis time period. For example, over the years 100–199, similar conclusions (as over the years 50–199) are obtained. NH warming under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.16\pm 0.04\) K) exceeds that under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (\(0.04\pm 0.04\) K), i.e., NH warming is muted under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). Furthermore, similar SH cooling occurs under both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) at \(-0.07\pm 0.03\) and \(-0.06\pm 0.04\) K, respectively. Globally, \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) yields net cooling at \(-0.07\pm 0.05\) K.The aerosol direct radiative effect (ADRE) and cloud radiative effect (CRE) are estimated from double radiation calls83. The tree restoration impacts the cloud radiative effect. For example, due to the surface darkening effect, the CRE has a negative contribution over tree restoration regions. Under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}-{{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), this issue is reduced but not necessarily eliminated. This issue is also not relevant over the ocean or for the ADRE.Methane effectsCAM6 with interactive chemistry30 constrains methane (CH4) to specified surface concentrations. This limits any changes, for example, through changes in oxidizing capacity, in the atmospheric concentration of methane. It is possible, however, to diagnose the change in CH4 concentration that would be expected, if it were not constrained, from the change in its lifetime:$$\frac{\Delta C}{C}={\left(\frac{\Delta \tau }{\tau }+1\right)}^{f}-1\approx f\frac{\Delta \tau }{\tau },$$where C is the atmospheric CH4 concentration, τ is the total CH4 lifetime including soil loss and f is the feedback of CH4 on its own lifetime with a value of \(1.30\pm 0.07\)45,46. We note that such offline methane calculations exclude important feedbacks. Given a C of 1775 ppb (representative of 2000 CH4 concentrations), a τ of 8.51 days in the year 2000 \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) control simulation and a corresponding Δτ of 0.348 days, we estimate an increase in the change in CH4 concentration from 89.3 to 99.5 ppb. For \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\), τ increases from 8.77 days in the year 2000 \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) control simulation to 9.71 days when our tree restoration perturbation is included, yielding a Δτ of 0.942 days. The corresponding change in CH4 concentration is 234.7–261.4 ppb.We use ref. 84 to calculate the ERF from the change in CH4 concentration, which is scaled downwards by 0.8 to account for CH4 shortwave absorption impacts on adjustments85,86. This is subsequently scaled by 1.52 to account for the additional chemical production of ozone and stratospheric water vapor46, i.e., total scaling is 1.22. This yields corresponding ERFs of 0.049 to 0.054 W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and 0.125 to 0.139 W m−2 under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\). We use a simple approximation to calculate the near-surface air temperature response, ΔTas = λ*ΕRF, where λ is the climate sensitivity parameter. Using an equilibrium climate sensitivity of 3 K with a 1−σ uncertainty range of 2.6–3.9 K87 and a 2 × CO2 ERF of 3.52 W m−2 with a 1−σ uncertainty range 0.36 W m−2 (ref. 88), λ has a best estimate of 0.85 (0.67–1.23) K per W m−2. We arrive at an approximate global mean temperature change associated with changes in CH4 of 0.04 (0.03–0.06) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) (as in ref. 24) and 0.13 (0.08–0.17) K under \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\).Surface energy balance (SEB) decompositionThe SEB decomposition35,47,48 is used to determine the contribution of surface energy fluxes to changes in surface temperature (ΔTs):$${\Delta T}_{{{{\rm{s}}}}}=\frac{1}{4\epsilon \sigma {{TS}}_{baseline}^{3}}\left[\Delta {SW}\left(1-\alpha \right)-\Delta \alpha \left({SW}\right)+\Delta {LW}-\Delta {LHF}-\Delta {SHF}\right],$$where σ is the Stefan–Boltzmann constant (\(5.67\times {10}^{-8}\) W m−2 K-4), ε is the surface emissivity with a value of 0.9735, and Ts,control is the surface temperature from the baseline experiment (i.e., without tree restoration). The first term in brackets represents the change in downwelling surface shortwave radiation (ΔSW) multiplied by the monthly climatology of (1−α); the second term in brackets represents the change in surface albedo (Δα) multiplied by the monthly climatology of SW; the third term in brackets represent the change in downwelling surface longwave radiation (ΔLW); the fourth term in brackets represents the change in surface latent heat flux (ΔLHF); and the final term in brackets represents the change in surface sensible heat flux (ΔSHF). The surface downwelling SW radiation term is also decomposed into contributions from clear-sky and cloudy-sky. The clear-sky contribution is estimated as \(\Delta {SW}_{{{\mathrm{clear}}}}\left(1-\alpha \right)\), where \(\Delta {SW}_{{{\mathrm{clear}}}}\) is the change in clear-sky downwelling surface solar radiation. The cloudy-sky contribution is estimated as the difference between the all-sky and clear-sky SW radiation SEB terms. A similar methodology is performed to decompose the surface longwave radiation term into clear-sky and cloudy-sky contributions. Not all factors are included in the SEB decomposition (e.g., ground heat flux, subsurface heat storage or changes in surface emissivity). Our SEB analysis is performed over land areas where the tree fraction increases by at least 0.1 and therefore provides an assessment of the regional effects of tree restoration. By restricting the SEB analysis to regions of relatively large tree fraction increases, we are isolating the local impacts of tree restoration on surface temperature, and radiative and turbulent heat fluxes. Such local effects are likely larger and more discernable than remote impacts.Fixed SST/sea ice (FSST) simulations to diagnose ERF and adjustmentsAnalogous CAM6 simulations (for both \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) with and without tree restoration) are conducted as above, but with climatologically fixed sea ice distributions and sea-surface temperatures (as opposed to using the slab ocean model). \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) simulations use the default CAM6 SST/sea ice data set for the year 2000 and present-day (year 2000) CO2 concentration. \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) simulations are identical, but the CO2 concentration is doubled, and the SST/sea ice fraction anomalies (years 50–199) from the CAM6 slab ocean \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{2{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) and \({{{{\rm{T}}}}{{{\rm{R}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}{{{\rm{E}}}}}_{1{x{{{\rm{C}}}}{{{\rm{o}}}}}_{2}}\) control experiments (i.e., without tree restoration) are added to the default CAM6 SST/sea ice data set. FSST simulations are integrated for 45 years. Our analysis uses the last 40 years. FSST integrations allow us to estimate the ERF, which is the top-of-the-atmosphere shortwave and longwave radiative flux difference between the tree restoration experiment and baseline. ERF is often used as a proxy for surface cooling (i.e., ERF< 0) or surface warming (i.e., ERF >0). The IRF and adjustments can also be obtained for FSST simulations. IRF does not include adjustments and is defined as the initial perturbation to the TOA radiation budget. Adjustments are flux changes as a consequence of changes in the atmospheric or surface state, which are unrelated to changes in surface temperature. ERF minus IRF is the total adjustment (Totaladj). Radiative kernels, which represent the radiative impacts from small perturbations in a state variable (e.g., humidity), are used to estimate non-cloud adjustments. A Python-based radiative kernel toolkit and the Geophysical Dynamics Laboratory radiative kernel89 are used here for the radiative kernel decomposition. The land surface corrected ERF (ERFts) is estimated by subtracting the surface temperature change adjustment from the ERF using the surface temperature radiative kernel. IRF is calculated from the surface albedo kernel (IRFalbedo)90. Here, however, we also assume the effects of enhanced aerosols (i.e., SOA) under tree restoration can be considered as an IRF. This IRFADRE is based on the aerosol direct radiative effect calculated online from double radiation calls (from the FSST simulations). The kernel difference method85,91 is used to estimate cloud adjustments (Cloudadj). Cloud adjustments are also estimated using the ISCCP simulator92,93,94, which provides an independent measure of the cloud adjustment (ISCCP Cloudadj).StatisticsSpatial response maps show significant changes at the 90% confidence level based on a two-tailed pooled t-test. The null hypothesis of zero difference with n1 + n2−2 degrees of freedom is evaluated, where n1 and n2 are the number of years in the experiment and control simulations (e.g., 150 years). The pooled variance \({S}_{{{p}}}^{2}=\frac{(n1-1){S}_{1}^{2}+(n2-1){S}_{2}^{2}}{n1+n2-2}\) is used, where \({S}_{1}^{2}\) and \({S}_{2}^{2}\) are the sample variances. Uncertainty estimates (i.e., error bars) are based on the ~90% confidence interval according to 1.65*Sp. Error bars in zonal average plots represent uncertainty across years.

Code availability
              
              CESM2 can be downloaded from NCAR at https://www.cesm.ucar.edu/models/cesm2/download. The Python-based radiative kernel toolkit and the GFDL radiative kernel can be downloaded from https://climate.rsmas.miami.edu/data/radiative-kernels/. Code used to quantify the cloud adjustment based on the ISCCP simulator, and the corresponding radiative kernels, can be downloaded from https://github.com/mzelinka/cloud-radiative-kernels. The APRP code can be downloaded from https://zenodo.org/records/8206763.

items.title: Widespread enhancement of ecosystem carbon fluxes during post moisture pulse
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 14 January 2026

Widespread enhancement of ecosystem carbon fluxes during post moisture pulse
                    Yu Bai 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-9914-022X1, Fangyue Zhang 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5479-62142, Philippe Ciais 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-8560-49433, Jean-Pierre Wigneron 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-5345-36184, Andrew F. Feldman 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-1547-69955,6, Pierre Gentine 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-0845-83457, William K. Smith 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-5785-64898, Joel A. Biederman 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-1831-461X9, Russell L. Scott9, Paul C. Stoy10, Dan Yakir 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-3381-139811, Armen R. Kemanian 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-7682-352712, David Makowski 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-6385-370313, Chuixiang Yi14,15 & …Zheng Fu 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0001-7627-88241 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

, Article number:  (2026)
            Cite this article
                    
                    
                    
                            We are providing an unedited version of this manuscript to give early access to its
                            findings. Before final publication, the manuscript will undergo further editing. Please note
                            there may be errors present which affect the content, and all legal disclaimers apply.

Subjects
        
            Carbon cycleClimate-change ecologyClimate-change impacts

AbstractRainfall pulses generate rapid increases and subsequent declines in soil moisture (SM), yet global ecosystem responses during SM dry-downs remain poorly quantified. Using 6502 soil dry-down events identified from global eddy-covariance observations, we compared carbon fluxes during dry-downs (treatment) to fluxes during the same periods without dry-downs in other years (control). During early dry-downs days, gross primary production (GPP) and respiration both exceeded controls, with stronger GPP gains enhancing net carbon uptake. This enhancement persisted for several days before diminishing as SM decreased and atmospheric dryness intensified. Latent and sensible heat fluxes also rose initially, but latent heat enhancement weakened over time, accompanied by enhanced sensible heat. Machine-learning analyses show that photosynthetic capacity and radiation drive positive GPP anomalies, while water limitations induce negative ones. Satellite data supported these patterns, whereas Earth system models underestimate their magnitude. These findings highlight transient pulse responses and support the broader applicability of the pulse-reserve paradigm.

Data availability
                  
                  The eddy covariance measurements are downloaded from FLUXNET2015 datasets (https://fluxnet.fluxdata.org/data/fluxnet2015-dataset/), AmeriFlux (https://ameriflux.lbl.gov/) and the ICOS (https://doi.org/10.18160/2G60-ZHAK). FLUXCOM GPP is obtained from http://fluxcom.org/CF-Products/. ERA5-Land reanalysis data are from https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/. TCSIF is downloaded from https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.8242928. Global Aridity Index is downloaded from https://csidotinfo.wordpress.com/2019/01/24/global-aridity-index-and-potential-evapotranspiration-climate-database-v3/. The CMIP6 data are downloaded from https://esgf-data.dkrz.de/search/cmip6-dkrz/.
               Code availability
                  
                  The code for reproducing main figures is available at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.30801074.

items.description: Educare i bambini alla sostenibilità ambientale è essenziale per costruire un futuro più verde. Attraverso la consapevolezza, le attività pratiche, il
items.body:
Casa
                             
                                                
                                        Educare i bambini alla sostenibilità ambientale

Educare i bambini alla sostenibilità ambientale è essenziale per costruire un futuro più verde. Attraverso la consapevolezza, le attività pratiche, il ruolo attivo dei genitori, le risorse educative e i progetti scolastici, possiamo insegnare ai più giovani l'importanza di prendersi cura del nostro pianeta.

Roberto Torcolacci

Gennaio 13, 2026

La chiave per un futuro sostenibile risiede nell’educazione delle nuove generazioni.

Educare i bambini alla consapevolezza ambientale sin da piccoli può avere un impatto significativo nel lungo termine.

È fondamentale iniziare con l’introdurre concetti come il rispetto della natura, l’importanza della biodiversità e il concetto di risorse rinnovabili e non rinnovabili.

Utilizzare esempi quotidiani, come il risparmio dell’acqua durante il lavaggio dei denti o l’uso efficiente della carta, aiuta i bambini a comprendere come le loro azioni influenzano il mondo intorno a loro.

Le fiabe, i cartoni animati e i libri illustrati sono ottimi strumenti per introdurre queste tematiche in modo accattivante e comprensibile.

Attività pratiche per insegnare la sostenibilità

Le attività manuali sono un mezzo efficace per insegnare la sostenibilità ai bambini.

Ad esempio, organizzare un’attività di piantumazione insegna il valore del verde e la responsabilità nella cura delle piante.

Le escursioni in natura offrono opportunità per osservare e discutere sul campo gli effetti dell’inquinamento e della deforestazione.

Creare oggetti riciclati, come giocattoli o strumenti musicali da materiali riciclato e riutilizzato, insegna l’importanza di ridurre i rifiuti.

Queste esperienze pratiche non solo educano alla sostenibilità ma sviluppano anche creatività e problem solving nei giovani apprendisti.

Il ruolo dei genitori nella guida al cambiamento

I genitori hanno un ruolo cruciale nell’educazione alla sostenibilità.

Sono i primi modelli di ruolo che i bambini osservano e da cui imparano.

Adottare uno stile di vita eco-sostenibile in casa, come il riciclo, l’uso di energie rinnovabili e una dieta basata su prodotti locali e stagionali, insegna con l’esempio l’importanza del rispetto ambientale.

Discutere delle notizie ambientali, partecipare insieme a iniziative locali di pulizia o sostenibilità e stimolare la riflessione critica sui consumi sono tutte azioni che rafforzano la consapevolezza e l’impegno dei bambini verso il pianeta.

Risorse educative per bambini eco-consapevoli

Esistono numerose risorse educative per supportare l’insegnamento della sostenibilità a bambini di tutte le età.

Libri, giochi, documentari e applicazioni didattiche sono strumenti utili per rendere l’apprendimento divertente e impegnativo.

Siti web specializzati offrono lezioni interattive e progetti fai-da-te su temi come il risparmio energetico, il riciclo e la conservazione dell’acqua.

Approfittare di queste risorse non solo arricchisce la conoscenza dei bambini ma aiuta anche a coltivare una coscienza ambientale fin dalla tenera età.

Progetti scolastici che promuovono la sostenibilità

Le scuole sono cruciali nell’inculcare la sostenibilità nelle menti giovani.

Progetti scolastici come giardini didattici, programmi di riciclaggio e concorsi di scienza focalizzati su tecnologie sostenibili promuovono la consapevolezza e l’impegno degli studenti.

Iniziative come le giornate verdi o le settimane tematiche sulla sostenibilità coinvolgono attivamente gli studenti in modi creativi e interattivi, facendo leva su un apprendimento collaborativo e orientato all’azione.

Tali programmi non solo educano, ma ispirano anche a diventare ambasciatori del cambiamento sostenibile nella propria comunità.

items.title: Gorilla di montagna, in Congo il raro parto di due gemelli
items.description:
Una coppia di gemelli di gorilla di montagna (Gorilla beringei beringei) è nata nella parte orientale della Repubblica Democratica del Congo
The post
items.body: In evidenza WWF Italia: 60 anni per la natura In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Un evento raro che dà speranza. Una coppia di gemelli di gorilla di montagna (Gorilla beringei beringei) è nata nella parte orientale della Repubblica Democratica del Congo. Per la precisione nel Parco Nazionale Virunga, il parco nazionale più antico e più grande dell’Africa, istituito 100 anni fa proprio per proteggere i gorilla di montagna Gli attivisti della comunità, che sabato hanno scoperto la gorilla ventiduenne Mafuko mentre abbracciava i suoi neonati, hanno affermato che la madre e i suoi due piccoli sembravano stare bene e in buona salute. Secondo le stime, i parti gemellari rappresentano circa l’1% di tutte le nascite di gorilla di montagna, anche se non sono disponibili dati precisi. L’ultima nascita di gemelli gorilla di montagna nel Parco Nazionale Virunga risale a oltre cinque anni fa (settembre 2020). Prima di allora sempre la stessa Mafuko aveva dato i natali ad altri due gemelli nel 2016. I due piccoli morirono però poche settimane dopo. Il WWF e lo sforzo per i gorilla di montagna La notizia del parto dei due gemelli aggiunge speranza al futuro del gorilla di montagna. Questo animale è una delle due sottospecie del gorilla orientale (Gorilla beringei). A differenza però del suo parente di pianura (Gorilla beringei graueri), la cui presenza si è ridotta del 77% nell’arco di una generazione, il gorilla di montagna rappresenta un importante esempio di successo di conservazione, raggiunto anche grazie agli sforzi del WWF. La sua popolazione ha infatti mostrato una crescita costante negli ultimi anni. Il numero di individui è salito da 254 nel 1981 ai 1.063 nel 2019. Questo aumento ha permesso la sua riclassificazione da “In Pericolo Critico” a “In Pericolo” da parte dell’IUCN. La strategia che si sta rivelando vincente si basa sul contrasto al bracconaggio grazie ad un monitoraggio quotidiano e ravvicinato degli individui da parte di ranger e biologi, in particolare nel Parco Nazionale dei Vulcani Virunga. Impegno che ha visto negli ultimi decenni il WWF protagonista, assieme ai ranger del parco.   Gorilla Scopri di più WWF Italy Press Office 1 Giugno 2018 Crescono i gorilla di montagna: oggi sono più di 1000 Il numero dei gorilla di montagna, sottospecie in forte pericolo di estinzione, sta crescendo. Ill merito va agli sforzi di conservazione che sono stati compiuti nell’area transfrontaliera dei vulcani Virunga, al confine fra Repubblica democratica del Congo, Ruanda e… Lucio Biancatelli 26 Gennaio 2018 Buon compleanno a Inguka e Inganda, i gorilla gemelli Nella Riserva di Dzanga Sangha (Repubblica Centroafricana) il WWF lavora al programma di abituazione di questi primati, per conciliare conservazione, turismo e ricerca scientifica Sono stati i primi gemellini di gorilla a nascere a Dzanga Sangha mai registrati… Lucio Biancatelli 22 Gennaio 2014 Nuovo nato tra i gorilla di montagna Proprio nei giorni in cui Dian Fossey, la zoologa americana che dedicò la vita allo studio e alla conservazione dei gorilla di montagna, e finì uccisa dai bracconieri, avrebbe compiuto 82 anni (il 16 gennaio), i ricercatori dell’International… Sara Bragonzi 20 Gennaio 2013 Gorilla di montagna Africa chiama Europa per salvare gli ultimi gorilla di montagna, appena 880 esemplari di questo possente animale africano, scampati al bracconaggio e alla deforestazione selvaggia che negli ultimi anni ha decimato la specie e oggi minacciati dallo spettro…
